transcript.text: [Music]
hey it's John Gerard I'm here with the
Fender acoustic guitar starter pack this
pack features the fender CD 60s guitar
but that's not all there's also a gig
bag there's a guitar strap an extra set
of strings and some guitar picks a
starter pack is a great way to begin as
a first-time player has everything you
need in one box so we're gonna unbox the
guitar take a look at the guitar itself
the parts what they're called how it all
works together and then we'll hear some
guitar tones so let's get started so
once we take everything out of the outer
box this is what we have we have your
guitar that's in the gig bag we have
your guitar picks the strings as well as
the guitar strap so now let's open up
the guitar and take a look alright here
we go so let's open up the bag here see
we got so first thing you'll notice this
brightly colored card here and that is
your fender play offer give you three
months free so if you're a first time
player this is a great place to learn if
you're a player already this is a great
place to learn some new skills or
techniques so put that down alright then
we have your allen wrench which is used
to adjust the truss rod we'll put that
aside for now and let's open this guitar
up here let's see again this is the
Fender CD 60s it's a dreadnought
acoustic guitar and that's in a natural
finish looks great we can take this
cover off the sound hole you just take
that right off should peel off all right
there we go
looks great alright so let's quickly
review the guitar itself all the parts
and what they do and I take this tag out
we could start with the headstock which
is this part here at the top of the neck
and then on the headstock we have your
tuners or machine heads and that's how
you tune the guitar we have three up top
and then three on the bottom the strings
run over the nut which is this piece
here and then we have the guitar neck
the flat part up top is
the fretboard and on the fret board we
have the frets and then you have
position markers here as well on the
fret board and then the guitar nick
attaches to the guitar body and so we
have your top these are the sides the
back of the guitar okay so this part
here is your sound hole this round
cutout now the construction of an
acoustic it's a larger body so there's a
lot of sound generating inside of the
guitar and this is where it comes out of
so the sound hole we have your pick art
here we have your bridge which includes
the saddle this long piece here this one
solid piece and then these are the pegs
and then if you were to change your
strings you would take a peg out you put
the string in and put the peg back in
that's what keeps the strings inside of
the bridge lastly we have your strap pin
so I'll show you in a bit how to put the
guitar strap on and these are the strap
pins where the strap attaches one here
and then one on the back of the guitar
here as well alright so let me show you
how to attach the guitar strap so let's
grab the strap here as you can see
there's two ends to the guitar strap
this end has a logo and I usually like
to put this end facing out so let's grab
this one first you can see there's a
little cutout and the material there so
it's gonna stretch out a little bit and
then go down through our strap pin okay
it's gonna take it and wrap it around
right through and then I'm gonna pull it
up make sure it's locked on all right so
then the other end of the strap goes to
the pin on the back of the guitar here
now this trap right out of the box is a
little bit too short for me so I'm going
to extend it out pulling down in that
buckle so we'll go almost all the way
out I pick up that slack and we're gonna
wrap it around my neck here and then
attach it to the pin on the back of the
guitar keep it on there just pull it up
make sure it's locked in it's fitting
now I'm through and now it feels pretty
comfortable and set just about right for
a sitting position alright so now that
we have the guitar strap attached let's
talk about tuning the guitar the ever
popular step of tuning your guitar so I
like to use the fender to nap it's very
convenient it's on my phone easily
downloadable
from the AppStore alright so we'll put
that down one note I want to make you
should be stretching your string
certainly if it's right out of the box
but also if you're changing your strings
and you have a fresh set of strings on
the guitar what that means is I'm just
gonna take one by one I'm gonna stretch
the strings out and what that does it
takes up some of the slack that might be
on the tuning pegs up here at the
headstock so one by one and you might
have to do this a couple times as you're
tuning alright so let's start on the
high E string
make sure you always tune up to the note
so you know how many slack on the tuning
pegs so we go down a little bit further
and then go back up
[Music]
okay there's your e moving on to the B
and then finally our low E string
[Music]
all right there we go
[Music]
sounds great so what I want to do now is
to show you the difference or actually
let you hear the difference between
playing with your fingers and a guitar
pick so let's grab one of the guitar
picks it comes with the guitar so if I
play with the pick you can hear that
crisp attack let's hear that right so if
I play for my fingers it's more like
this all right so it's a little bit more
subtle a little warmer than using the
pick but both ways are fine it's up to
you how you choose to play the guitar
and don't forget if you break a string
don't fear because you have an extra set
of strings that come with the guitar
pack these are a set of 12 if you're
wondering how often you might have to
change your strings I would say usually
every couple months every two to three
months or every 80 to 100 hours that you
might be playing so you just kind of
gauge it once you see the strings
turning darker or they sound a little
bit more dull than it's probably time to
change the strings and then lastly make
sure you know where your allen wrench is
keep it handy at some point you may need
to make an adjustment on your neck and
that's done inside the sound hole right
in here alright thanks for tuning in to
check out the Fender acoustic guitar
starter pack featuring this beautiful CD
60s acoustic guitar and in the pack we
also throw in the gig bag we have the
guitar strap we have an extra set of
strings and some guitar picks so if
you're unboxing your own at home I hope
you're enjoying it you can go to fender
comm for more information and stay tuned
for more videos we'll see you
[Music]
[Music]
